1908.07816.text: However, they do not explicitly learn the subtle emotional interactions captured in human dialogs.
1908.07816.label: Background

1908.07816.text: chatbots, affective computing, deep learning, natural language processing
1908.07816.label: Other

1908.07816.text: In this paper, we propose a multi-turn dialog system aimed at learning and generating emotional responses that so far only humans know how to do.
1908.07816.label: Objective

1908.07816.text: Open-domain dialog systems (also known as chatbots) have increasingly drawn attention in natural language processing. Some of the recent work aims at incorporating affect information into sequence-to-sequence neural dialog modeling, making the response emotionally richer, while others use hand-crafted rules to determine the desired emotion response.
1908.07816.label: Objective

1908.07816.text: Further human evaluations confirm that our chatbot can keep track of the conversation context and generate emotionally more appropriate responses while performing equally well on grammar.
1908.07816.label: Result

1908.07816.text: Compared with two baseline models, offline experiments show that our method performs the best in perplexity scores.
1908.07816.label: Result

1810.11143.text: Communities who suffer from poor air quality often rely on experts to identify pollution sources due to the lack of accessible tools.
1810.11143.label: Background

1810.11143.text: Urban air pollution has been linked to various human health considerations, including cardiopulmonary diseases.
1810.11143.label: Background

1810.11143.text: These reports are also sent to the local health department and visualized on a map along with air quality data from monitoring stations.
1810.11143.label: Background

1810.11143.text: Taking this into account, we developed Smell Pittsburgh , a system that enables community members to report odors and track where these odors are frequently concentrated.
1810.11143.label: Background

1810.11143.text: Additionally, with these reports and air quality data, we developed a model to predict upcoming smell events and send push notifications to inform communities.
1810.11143.label: Background

1810.11143.text: Citizen science, smell, air quality, sustainable HCI, machine learning, community empowerment
1810.11143.label: Other

1810.11143.text: This visualization provides a comprehensive overview of the local pollution landscape.
1810.11143.label: Result

1810.11143.text: Our evaluation of this system demonstrates that engaging residents in documenting their experiences with pollution odors can help identify local air pollution patterns, and can empower communities to advocate for better air quality.
1810.11143.label: Result

1810.11143.text: All smell report data are publicly accessible online.
1810.11143.label: Other

2010.07358.text: Many such taskssuch as house cleaning, packing for a trip, or organizing a living spacecan be characterized as object-rearrangement tasks defined by users navigating through an environment, picking up objects, and placing them in different locations.
2010.07358.label: Background

2010.07358.text: Augmented-reality (AR) glasseswhich will have access to real-time, high-fidelity data regarding a users environment via onboard sensors, as well as an ability to seamlessly display real-time information to the userpresent a unique opportunity to provide users with assistance in completing quotidian tasks.
2010.07358.label: Background

2010.07358.text: In this initial study, we assume that the AR systems observations include a map of the environment and real-time localization of the objects and user within that map.
2010.07358.label: Background

2010.07358.text: In particular, we study the effect of our proposed AR assistance on users task performance and sense of agency over a range of task difficulties.
2010.07358.label: Background

2010.07358.text: These modeling choices allow us to formalize the problem of computing AR assistance for any object-rearrangement task as a planning problem that reduces to solving a capacitated vehicle-routing problem (CVRP), which is a variant of the classical traveling salesman problem (TSP) in combinatorial optimization.
2010.07358.label: Background

2010.07358.text: The embodied agent comprises a hybrid between the AR system and the user, in that it has the observation space (i.e., sensor measurements) of the AR system and the action space (i.e., task-execution actions) of the user; its policy is learned by minimizing the the time to complete the task.
2010.07358.label: Method

2010.07358.text: (b) We also introduce a novel AR simulator based on Habitat [37] that can enable large-scale web-based evaluation of AR-like assistance (Image courtesy [39]).
2010.07358.label: Method

2010.07358.text: We introduce a novel framework for computing and displaying AR assistance that consists of (1) associating an optimal action sequence with the policy of an embodied agent and (2) presenting this optimal action sequence to the user as suggestion notifications in the AR systems heads-up display.
2010.07358.label: Method

2010.07358.text: In addition, we introduce a novel AR simulator that can enable web-based evaluation of AR-like assistance and associated large-scale data collection; our approach is based on the Habitat [37] simulator for embodied artificial intelligence (AI).
2010.07358.label: Method

2010.07358.text: Additionally, we show that while users report a negative impact to their agency, that they may prefer this when presented with a system that aides them in task completion.
2010.07358.label: Result

2010.07358.text: (a) We present a novel framework for AR assistance in object-rearrangement tasks such as house cleaning that leverages an embodied user-AR hybrid agent and a capacitated vehicle routing problem (CVRP) formulation to compute and display the optimal action sequence for the task to the user in AR.
2010.07358.label: Method

2010.07358.text: We perform the study at scale using Amazon
2010.07358.label: Result

2010.07358.text: Finally, we perform a study that evaluates how users respond to the AR assistance generated by the proposed framework on a specific quotidian object-rearrangement taskhouse cleaningusing our proposed AR simulator.
2010.07358.label: Result

2010.07358.text: (c) We deploy our framework on Amazon Mechanical Turk[3]tostudytheeffectofourproposedARassistanceonuserstaskperformanceandsenseofagencyoverarangeoftaskdifficulties.
2010.07358.label: Result

2010.07358.text: Mechanical Turk (AMT) [3] and collect data using psiTurk [20].
2010.07358.label: Other

2010.07358.text: Our results indicate that providing users with the proposed form of AR assistance improves the users overall performance.
2010.07358.label: Result

2103.06807.text: However, effects on users are hard to predict as they depend on factors that are latent and evolve over the course of interaction.
2103.06807.label: Background

2103.06807.text: A carelessly picked adaptation may impose high costs to the user  for example, due to surprise or relearning effort  or trap the process to a suboptimal design immaturely.
2103.06807.label: Background

2103.06807.text: Adapting an interface requires taking into account both the positive and negative effects that changes may have on the user.
2103.06807.label: Background

2103.06807.text: We propose a novel approach for adaptive user interfaces that yields a conservative adaptation policy: It finds beneficial changes when there are such and avoids changes when there are none.
2103.06807.label: Background

2103.06807.text: Adaptive User Interfaces; Reinforcement Learning; Predictive Models; Monte Carlo Tree Search
2103.06807.label: Background

2103.06807.text: method plans sequences of adaptations and consults predictive HCI models to estimate their effects.
2103.06807.label: Method

2103.06807.text: We present empirical and simulation results from the case of adaptive menus, showing that the method outperforms both a non-adaptive and a frequency-based policy.
2103.06807.label: Result

2104.03820.text: Generative models have become adept at producing artifacts such as images, videos, and prose at human-like levels of proficiency.
2104.03820.label: Background

2104.03820.text: The artifacts produced in this way may contain imperfections, such as compilation or logical errors.
2104.03820.label: Background

2104.03820.text: New generative techniques, such as unsupervised neural machine translation (NMT), have recently been applied to the task of generating source code, translating it from one programming language to another.
2104.03820.label: Background

2104.03820.text: Our three-stage scenario sparked discussions about the utility and desirability working with an imperfect AI system, how acceptance of that systems outputs would be established, and future opportunities generative AI in application modernization.
2104.03820.label: Background

2104.03820.text: We examine the extent to which software engineers would tolerate such imperfections and explore ways to aid the detection and correction of those errors.
2104.03820.label: Background

2104.03820.text: Our study highlights how UI features such as confidence highlighting and alternate translations help software engineers work with and better understand generative NMT models.
2104.03820.label: Result

2104.03820.text: Using a design scenario approach, we interviewed 11 software engineers to understand their reactions to the use of an NMT model in the context of application modernization, focusing on the task translating source code from one language to another.
2104.03820.label: Method

2102.08235.text: With the growing ubiquity of wearable devices, sensed physiological responses provide new means to connect with others.
2102.08235.label: Background

2102.08235.text: However, the addition of biosignals introduced concerns about autonomy and agency over the messages they sent.
2102.08235.label: Background

2102.08235.text: While recent research demonstrates the expressive potential for biosignals, the value of sharing these personal data remains unclear.
2102.08235.label: Background

2102.08235.text: computer-mediated communication, biosignals, interpersonal communication, social connection, smartwatches, heart rate, couples
2102.08235.label: Background

2102.08235.text: In a one-month study with 20 couples, participants used Significant Otter with biosignals sensing OFF and ON.
2102.08235.label: Background

2102.08235.text: We discuss design implications and future directions for communication systems that recommend messages based on biosignals.
2102.08235.label: Background

2102.08235.text: We found that while sensing OFF enabled couples to keep in touch, sensing ON enabled easier and more authentic communication that fostered social connection.
2102.08235.label: Background

2102.08235.text: To understand their role in communication, we created Significant Otter, an Apple Watch/iPhone app that enables romantic partners to share and respond to each others biosignals in the form of animated otter avatars.
2102.08235.label: Background

2102.09039.text: User interface design is a complex task that involves designers examining a wide range of options.
2102.09039.label: Background

2102.09039.text: Based on our experiments, Spacewalker allows designers to effectively search a large design space of a UI, using the language they are familiar with, and improve their design rapidly at a minimal cost.
2102.09039.label: Result

2102.09039.text: Markup language, crowdsourcing, design search, tools, genetic programming
2102.09039.label: Background

2102.09039.text: We enhanced a genetic algorithm to accommodate crowd worker responses from pairwise comparison of UI designs, which is crucial for obtaining reliable feedback.
2102.09039.label: Method

2102.09039.text: We present Spacewalker, a tool that allows designers to rapidly search a large design space for an optimal web UI with integrated support.
2102.09039.label: Method

2102.09039.text: Spacewalker then parses the annotated HTML specification, and intelligently generates and distributes various configurations of the web UI to crowd workers for evaluation.
2102.09039.label: Background

2102.09039.text: Designers first annotate each attribute they want to explore in a typical HTML page, using a simple markup extension we designed.
2102.09039.label: Background

2101.11778.text: Consequently, many people feel a lack of agency over their app use, which is linked to negative life effects such as loss of sleep.
2101.11778.label: Background

2101.11778.text: In the attention economy, video apps employ design mechanisms like autoplay that exploit psychological vulnerabilities to maximize watch time.
2101.11778.label: Background

2101.11778.text: Prior design research has innovated external mechanisms that police multiple apps, such as lockout timers.
2101.11778.label: Background

2101.11778.text: We discuss implications for how designers can help users reclaim a sense of agency over their media use.
2101.11778.label: Background

2101.11778.text: digital wellbeing, sense of agency, social media, YouTube
2101.11778.label: Other

2101.11778.text: In this work, we shift the focus to how the internal mechanisms of an app can support user agency, taking the popular YouTube mobile app as a test case.
2101.11778.label: Objective

2101.11778.text: From a survey of 120 U.S. users, we find that autoplay and recommendations primarily undermine sense of agency, while search and playlists support it.
2101.11778.label: Result

2101.11778.text: From 13 co-design sessions, we find that when users have a specific intention for how they want to use YouTube they prefer interfaces that support greater agency.
2101.11778.label: Result

2102.00625.text: How to attribute responsibility for autonomous artificial intelligence (AI) systems actions has been widely debated across the humanities and social science disciplines.
2102.00625.label: Background

2102.00625.text: We discuss policy and HCI implications of these findings, such as the need for explainable AI in high-stakes scenarios.
2102.00625.label: Background

2102.00625.text: AI, Moral Responsibility, Responsibility, Moral Judgment, Blame, Liability, COMPAS, Bail Decision-Making
2102.00625.label: Background

2102.00625.text: However, there was a meaningful difference in how people perceived these agents moral responsibility; human agents were ascribed to a higher degree of present-looking and forward-looking notions of responsibility than AI agents.
2102.00625.label: Result

2102.00625.text: We also found that people expect both AI and human decision-makers and advisors to justify their decisions regardless of their nature.
2102.00625.label: Result

2102.00625.text: This work presents two experiments (  =200 each) that measure peoples perceptions of eight different notions of moral responsibility concerning AI and human agents in the context of bail decision-making.
2102.00625.label: Background

2102.00625.text: Using reallife adapted vignettes, our experiments show that AI agents are held causally responsible and blamed similarly to human agents for an identical task.
2102.00625.label: Result

2102.09087.text: With phone form factor as auxiliary information, TapNet can jointly learn from data across devices and simultaneously recognize multiple tap properties, including tap direction and tap location.
2102.09087.label: Background

2102.09087.text: Along with the datasets, codebase 1 , and extensive experiments, TapNet establishes a new technical foundation for off-screen mobile input.
2102.09087.label: Background

2102.09087.text: We present the design, training, implementation and applications of TapNet, a multi-task network that detects tapping on the smartphone.
2102.09087.label: Background

2102.09087.text: We developed two datasets consisting of over 135K training samples, 38K testing samples, and 32 participants in total.
2102.09087.label: Background

2102.09087.text: To make off-screen interaction without specialized hardware practical, we investigate using deep learning methods to process the common built-in IMU sensor (accelerometers and gyroscopes) on mobile phones into a useful set of one-handed interaction events.
2102.09087.label: Method

2102.09087.text: Experimental evaluation demonstrated the effectiveness of the TapNet design and its significant improvement over the state of the art.
2102.09087.label: Result

2102.04174.text: Informed by user performance, the psychologist component updates its beliefs about each users memory state for each item.
2102.04174.label: Background

2102.04174.text: Whereas previous work has focused on either personalization of teaching or optimization of teaching intervention sequences, the proposed individualized model-based planning approach represents convergence of these two lines of research.
2102.04174.label: Background

2102.04174.text: The approach is novel in its use of a cognitive model that can account for several key individualand material-specific characteristics related to recall/forgetting, along with a planning technique that considers users practice schedules.
2102.04174.label: Background

2102.04174.text: Model-based planning picks the best interventions via interactive learning of a user memory models parameters.
2102.04174.label: Background

2102.04174.text: The paper presents a novel model-based method for intelligent tutoring, with particular emphasis on the problem of selecting teaching interventions in interaction with humans.
2102.04174.label: Background

2102.04174.text: To predict the consequences of particular candidate sequences for the human learner, the planner component consults the psychologist; then, the planner chooses the teaching intervention that maximizes the potential for meeting the learning objective.
2102.04174.label: Objective

2102.04174.text: We propose a model-based planning approach for intelligent tutoring that combines parameter inference and sequence planning.
2102.04174.label: Objective

2102.04174.text: Taking a rule-based approach as a baseline, the authors evaluated the methods benefits in a controlled study of artificial teaching in second-language vocabulary learning (  = 53).
2102.04174.label: Result

2108.11259.text: While all agents were curious and enthusiastic, the style of humour was manipulated such that the agent either expressed an affiliative style, a self-defeating style, or no humour.
2108.11259.label: Background

2108.11259.text: Previous studies have highlighted the benefits of pedagogical conversational agents using socially-oriented conversation with students.
2108.11259.label: Background

2108.11259.text: In this work, we examine the effects of a conversational agents use of affiliative and self-defeating humour  considered conducive to social well-being and enhancing interpersonal relationships  on learners perception of the agent and attitudes towards the task.
2108.11259.label: Background

2108.11259.text: Conversational Agent, Education, Motivation, Learning Experience, Learning Outcomes, Humour
2108.11259.label: Other

2108.11259.text: Using a between-subjects protocol, 58 participants taught a conversational agent about rock classification using a learning-by-teaching platform, the Curiosity Notebook.
2108.11259.label: Background

2108.11259.text: Results demonstrate that affiliative humour can significantly increase motivation and effort, while self-defeating humour, although enhancing effort, negatively impacts enjoyment.
2108.11259.label: Result

2108.11259.text: Findings further highlight the importance of understanding learner characteristics when using humour.
2108.11259.label: Result

2102.00593.text: Decision support tools (DSTs) embodying machine learning models may help improve the treatment selection process, but often fail in clinical practice due to poor system integration.
2102.00593.label: Background

2102.00593.text: While many antidepressant medications are available, few clinical guidelines support choosing among them.
2102.00593.label: Background

2102.00593.text: Major depressive disorder is a debilitating disease affecting 264 million people worldwide.
2102.00593.label: Background

2102.00593.text: We identify ways in which DSTs need to engage with the healthcare sociotechnical system, including clinical processes, patient preferences, resource constraints, and domain knowledge.
2102.00593.label: Method

2102.00593.text: We use an iterative, co-design process to investigate clinicians perceptions of using DSTs in antidepressant treatment decisions.
2102.00593.label: Method

2102.00593.text: Through this work, we demonstrate how current trends in explainable AI may be inappropriate for clinical environments and consider paths towards designing these tools for real-world medical systems.
2102.00593.label: Result

2102.00593.text: Our results suggest that clinical DSTs should be designed as multi-user systems that support patient-provider collaboration and offer on-demand explanations that address discrepancies between predictions and current standards of care.
2102.00593.label: Result

2102.00593.text: decision support tools, healthcare, major depressive disorder
2102.00593.label: Other

2104.04842.text: However, designing an effective interview chatbot is non-trivial.
2104.04842.label: Background

2104.04842.text: Few tools exist to help designers design, evaluate, and improve an interview chatbot iteratively.
2104.04842.label: Background

2104.04842.text: and offer design suggestions for improving the chatbot based on such metrics.
2104.04842.label: Background

2104.04842.text: Recent studies show the effectiveness of interview chatbots for information elicitation.
2104.04842.label: Result

2104.04842.text: Based on a formative study and literature reviews, we propose a computational framework for quantifying the performance of interview chatbots.
2104.04842.label: Objective

2104.04842.text: To validate the effectiveness of iChatProfile , we designed and conducted a between-subject study that compared the performance of 10 interview chatbots designed with or without using iChatProfile .
2104.04842.label: Result

2104.04842.text: Conversational AI Agents; Interview Chatbot; Chatbot Debugging; Chatbot Evaluation Framework; Chatbot Design Suggestion; Automatic Chatbot Profiling; Automatic Chatbot Evaluation
2104.04842.label: Result

2104.04842.text: Incorporating the framework, we have developed iChatProfile , an assistive chatbot design tool that can automatically generate a profile of an interview chatbot with quantified performance metrics
2104.04842.label: Result

2104.04842.text: Based on the live chats between the 10 chatbots and 1349 users, our results show that iChatProfile helped the designers build significantly more effective interview chatbots, improving both interview quality and user experience.
2104.04842.label: Result
